page.title: 03Ryton Gravel Pits Lake
page.content: Ryton Gravel pits lake is part of the belt of sand and gravel south of Bubbenhall of the Pleistocene period of glacial outwash and commercially very valuable.When excavations removed the sand,the gravel was found to be so saturated in water,that it could not be lifted onto the processing belt,and so water pumps were brought in.The result was a drastic alteration in the water table,effecting Mr.Smith at Shrubs Lodge Farm.When workings ceased,a steep sided lake 4-6m high with various sized islands was formed, covering some 10 hectares. In 1977,it formed part a Wetland Survey by Warnact. Considerable birdlife was observed and floristically interesting considering the poor sandy soil.A small amount of landscaping has been done,more is proposed,but too much could endanger dragonfly habitit.
